COME SIT WITH ME

These SHORT ESSAY STYLE CHAPTERS by some of my favorite @incourage authors is the perfect ways to wrap up 2022. 

Being human is hard. Being in relationships with other humans is even harder. People are complex and relationships are messy but loving one another well is possible. Whether navigating political or religious differences, or dealing with toxic people or our own unforgiveness, this book tackles the struggles no one really wants to talk about. But there is hope! We can actually grow closer to God and others through the circumstances we'd rather run from.

DIRECT LINK CAN BE FOUND IN MY STORIES TODAY! 

In Come Sit with Me, 26 (in)courage writers help you navigate tough relational tensions by revealing their own hard-fought, grace-filled learning moments. They show you how to

· delight in your differences
· honor and value others even when you disagree
· connect before you correct
· trust that God is working even when people disappoint you
· live and love like Jesus by serving others

Whether you're in the middle of a conflict without resolution or wondering how to enter into a friend's pain, this book will serve as a gentle guide. Discover how God can work through your disagreements, differences, and discomfort in ways you might never expect.

HAVE YOU EVER READ THROUGH THE BIBLE?⁠
⁠
This quote by Augustine reminds me of the first time I started at the beginning and read all the way through to the end. It was mind-blowing! Not only was my Bible readable… it was applicable! ⁠
⁠
But my biggest discovery was just how cohesive it was… it all went together so beautifully! By the time Jesus hit the scene in Matthew 1:1, I couldn’t help but CHEER! I had been reading about Him, longing for Him, throughout the Old Testament chapters! I was more ready than ever to see Him fulfill every bit of every law… atone for every sin… make way for every blessing!⁠
⁠
Jesus was the MESSENGER who made clear every message the Father had been trying to send since the beginning of time!⁠
⁠
I’m reminded of this Bible verse:⁠
⁠
“Don’t misunderstand why I have come. I did not come to abolish the law of Moses or the writings of the prophets. No, I came to accomplish their purpose. (Matthew 5:17)⁠
⁠
Are you ready to start reading your Bible as though it is readable and applicable, and one cohesive and exciting story of rescue, redemption, and relationship? ⁠
⁠
IT IS!⁠
⁠

There have been seasons in my life when my Bible reading has felt “dry as a stick”, as Paul Bunyan once wrote. But other times when it’s read like a living-breathing love letter sent just to me… in that very moment. Living, active, and applicable to my life and heart right then. ⁠
⁠
Are you in a dry season right now? Or perhaps you’re in a wonderfully meaningful season where God’s Word is actively, tenderly ministering to you.⁠
⁠
As I get ready to launch The 40-Day Feast (January 17, 2023) God’s Word has been thrillingly alive and I am so grateful for my time with Him. Though it’s been a long season in the book of Job (in a Job-like season of my life, I confess), God has shown me such tender loving-kindness in the pages of this loving letter.⁠
⁠
Again, I’m asking you to share… Are you in a parched-dry season or a living-loving season with God in His Word? ⁠
⁠
Find out more about The 40-Day Feast at Wendyspeake.com/feast⁠

I was sitting in the audience at a Christmas Tea in our local church a number of years ago when 1 Corinthians 1:18 was shared. Though I had read my Bible cover to cover a number of times over the course of my life, the verse caught my attention as if I was hearing it (truly hearing it) for the first time ever. Here’s what it says: ⁠
⁠
“For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.” (1 Corinthians 1:18, NIV)⁠
⁠
With only 1 week until we celebrate Christmas with our families and friends I pray that you take a moment to consider if you’ve accepted or rejected the true gift of Christmas… The Christ-child we celebrate every December 25th! ⁠
⁠
If you have accepted Him, have you accepted His Word?  I’d love to encourage you to spend time reading through God’s Word (your Bible) during these holidays, and then keep reading as you enter the new year. ⁠
⁠
If you are a Bible believer, commit to being a Bible reader. ⁠
⁠
And if you aren’t a Bible believer, choosing instead to reject God, I’d still like to encourage you to become a Bible reader. Spend some time humbly opening a Bible up to the Book of John and reading it with an open heart this Christmas. ⁠
⁠
Give Him a chance to reveal Himself to you this Christmas season!⁠
⁠
Love, ⁠
Wendy⁠
⁠

The merriest of Christmas wishes to you and yours — from me and mine! (Part 1)

After a year of unspoken (and unposted) struggles, family togetherness feels like a balm this holiday. 

With very personal empathy for those of you who have persevered through difficulties of your own with your eyes on Christ, clinging to His promises, in 2022, I pray that you and your beloveds have moments of true peace and joy, love and laughter sprinkled throughout these Christ-centered days! 

And a very special thank you to the most wonderful family photographer in all of North Texas @amber.dion — your willingness to prioritize my last minute request for a holiday shoot blessed my heart BIG TIME! And when the snow flurries began to fall and fly… your excitement matched my own!

While you may have enhanced the snow flakes just a bit in some of these shots… these photos are exactly how my memories will remain, frozen forever. 

Tears of gratitude! 

Merry Christmas one and all!

Merry Christmas (part 2) 

The very first morning we spent together as a family this holiday… we all bundled up and headed to @martybscoffee to celebrate our togetherness! Specifically, we were were having a birthday party for my Christmas baby! 

Before celebrating Christ’s birth each year, we take our sweet time celebrating the birth of our oldest son, my first-born miracle, Caleb. 

Nineteen years ago this child made me a mom, a week before Christmas. And loving him has been one of the absolute joys of my life!

Today is Christmas Eve, and we are transitioning into our Christmas time traditions. Our annual ornaments were gifted at the breakfast table. Carols are playing and cider is simmering. This afternoon we will go to church for a time of heartfelt worship — then home again for a family feast. We will wrap things up by watching The Nativity, like we do each year on Christmas Eve. 

This is my family. These are our precious traditions. 

A very sincere thank you to photographer @amber.dion for joining us for our celebration to capture some of our family love with Caleb. I’ll treasure these pictures for a very long time. 🤍

This is my story, ⁠
this is my song.⁠
On Christmas morning, ⁠
and all year long!⁠
⁠
When God, the light of the world, penetrated my darkness, my soul got all lit up. But it didn’t just happen once, at the moment of my salvation. Every time I set my struggle under the lamplight of God’s Love… I find my worth again. ⁠
Merry Christmas friends!⁠
⁠
O holy night, the stars are brightly shining,⁠
It is the night of the dear Saviour’s birth;⁠
Long lay the world in sin and error pining,⁠
'Till he appeared and the soul felt its worth.⁠
A thrill of hope the weary world rejoices,⁠
For yonder breaks a new and glorious morn;⁠
Chorus⁠
Fall on your knees, Oh hear the angel voices!⁠
O night divine! O night when Christ was born.⁠
O night, O holy night, O night divine.⁠
⁠

⁠
If you are a Bible-believer but not necessarily a Bible-reader (apart from these familiar Christmas passages) let me invite you to become one in the new year! ⁠
⁠
Whether you simply want to keep reading where the Christmas story left off or go to the beginning of Genesis and start there, I encourage you to make a plan. ⁠
⁠
And speaking of “plans”, I have a couple of Bible reading plans available for download over on wendyspeake.com/feast ⁠

Here it is… my final book recommendation of 2022!

Sanctuary: Cultivating a quiet heart in a noisy and demanding world by @denisejhughes was one of my favorite read this year! 

(Link in stories today!

Written in an easy to read and apply devotional format, Denise leads us through 31 days, helping us to cultivate a quieter, more worshipful life. 

I’ve had a few gals reach out to me privately asking me for a supplemental book to read during our upcoming Sugar Fast (beginning January 9th) and while it has nothing to do with our relationship with food… it’s a quiet invitation to sit with Jesus rather than anything and everything else you’ve been sitting with in recent days. No food, no phone, no movies, no shopping can usher you into God’s sanctuary. 

This book can. 

“Come to Me, and I will give you rest.” (Jesus)

Yesterday I posted a simple question: What is your “One Word” for 2023? ⁠
⁠
Choosing a word to guide us into the new year is a wonderful practice and I have loved doing this myself. However, this year, I realized that there is ONE WORD that holds the answer to every other word we choose as our guiding question. ⁠
⁠
Year after year I hear from my online friends that they have chosen wonderful words like these: ⁠
⁠
JOY ⁠
HOPE⁠
SHINE⁠
PEACE⁠
COURAGE⁠
ENDURANCE⁠
FORGIVENESS… ⁠
⁠
While all of these are good and Godly themes, I’ve come to see that the best way to learn and understand and practice and grow to embody each one is to search the Scriptures for guidance! All these themes are spoken of in God’s living, active, and oh-so-applicable Word. And so, this year, my 𝗺𝘆 𝗢𝗡𝗘 𝗪𝗢𝗥𝗗 𝗶𝘀 𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗪𝗢𝗥𝗗. My Bible is the banner over every need and every area of my personal and Spiritual development. God speaks into every part of my life where I still need to grow up and mature. In every unrefined area that He longs to refine, His Word is the tool to get the job done! ⁠
⁠
In God’s Word I find the path to peace: in His Holy Communication I hear His voice telling me where my ultimate hope can be found; in the Scriptures I discover where pure JOY is too; and in my Bible I find explanations on how to endure and why, as well as how to forgive and why.⁠
⁠
It’s all there! ⁠
⁠
While I love reading through my Bible from Genesis to Revelation, I also love searching the Scriptures for specific verses regarding a topic that I want to understand more fully and humbly apply to my life. That is why, I created a topical study guide as one of the free gifts I’m giving away for those who pre-order my new book, The 40-Day Feast (which releases January 17). ⁠
⁠

Prayerfully make your plans, my friends. Absolutely! 

Seek His Will and ask for His wisdom. Humbly hold your desires and motivations up to the light of God’s Word with a teachable, moldable, submissive heart. This is how we are to make our plans. 

All good and Biblical counsel, yes? 

But don’t forget to trust God as you walk those plans out, moment-by-moment and day-by-day. 

As plans seemingly shift — or fall apart altogether — and confusion and fear threaten, keep in step with Christ as He walks you through your UNPLANNED challenges. 

Though challenges come (and that’s guaranteed)  He will never leave nor forsake you. Though you question His seemingly clear, kind leading, do not question His goodness. 

Though it feels like He’s sent you off the path you thought He would lovingly lead you down, He will lovingly lead you through. So don’t you leave the light-bright illuminating radiance of His presence when the steps seem dark and scary.

Persevere in faith today, my friends. Seek the Lord, Hold onto Him. Stay put upon the stabilizing rock of His presence, Christ’s personhood and loving-kindness, when the winds of confusion blow!

This is the Scripture, the passage, the entire Psalm-song I’m singing out loud each day as a reminder to my own heart during a treacherous season. 

Dear friends, more often than not we  take our fears and failures to Starbucks, Netflix, and Amazon Prime. We take our hurts and holes to food, as though that will make us whole… and holy. But it doesn’t. 

We take refuge in our pantries and freezers. With a fork in one hand and a phone in the other we try to numb the pain. We must refuse that quick and short-term fix, and choose instead to fix our eyes on Him — and run into Him! 

He is the only one able to fix us and the battles we face. 

So keep your feet planted firmly upon the rock — Jesus is the steadfast and secure, stable and stabilizing, rock of our Salvation. 

He is our fortress too! Our defender in times of trouble. So don’t just run to Him, run into Him and close the door! Let Him be your stronghold, and find your rest in His strong hold. 

Let Him defend and shield you and bring you to a place of horn-blowing victory. 

Remember that running into Jesus as our stronghold sets us free… but taking our pain and problems to other things to satisfy and save only leads to more problems.  A different stronghold all together. Addiction and anxiety. More emotional pain and possibly physical and relational pain too. 

Our food and phones are not meant to satisfy or save us. Only Jesus. So run into Him today!

Both are true. 

We must watch what we say with intentionality, as we intentionally meditate on thoughts that please God. 

God’s thoughts are pleasing thoughts. Yes, God’s thoughts please God. So I often remind myself (sometimes mid-thought) to take my thoughtless words captive and turn my attention to His Word. 

But that doesn’t happen accidentally — only purposefully — and maybe even defiantly! Meditating on God’s Word requires defiantly saying no to the present, prevailing messages all around us — even within us in the form of emotions and false belief systems. 

We must actively guard our thoughts, but as we do we must also guard our mouths. 

The reality is that these two Spiritual disciplines go hand-in-hand. For what we meditate on we become. We become what we behold. What we think upon we act upon. The words that cycle through our thought-life eventually spill out in our daily—life. 

And so, today, I am holding thoughts captive that are not pleasing and acceptable — but damaging, untrue, and ungodly. I am choosing instead to allow God’s thoughts to shape my thoughts — knowing that if I do, His thoughts will shape my behavior — as His Word influences my words. 

We need to watch what we say, so that we might speak words that build up and bring life and represent the One who is transforming us (ever so slowly I’m afraid) into a more beautiful representation of Himself. But it starts with what we think upon. 

Yes. 

“We demolish arguments and every pretension that sets itself up against the knowledge of God, and we take captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ.” (2 Corinthians 10:5, NIV)

“Let the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be acceptable in your sight, O Lord, my rock and my redeemer.” (‭‭Psalm‬ ‭19‬:‭14‬ , ESV‬)

Here is the Amazon description: 

“In 1760, Deborah Samson is born to Puritan parents in Plympton, Massachusetts. When her father abandons the family and her mother is unable to support them, Deborah is bound out as an indentured servant. From that moment on, she yearns for a life of liberation and adventure.

Twenty years later, as the American colonies begin to buckle in their battle for independence, Deborah, impassioned by the cause, disguises herself as a soldier and enlists in the Continental Army. Her impressive height and lanky build make her transformation a convincing one, and it isn’t long before she finds herself confronting the horrors of war head-on.

But as Deborah fights for her country’s freedom, she must contend with the secret of who she is―and, ultimately, a surprising love she can’t deny.”

I have two very dear friends battling cancer right now. 

Dr. Michelle Bengtson has been persevering in faith and ministry for multiple years, through multiple surgeries and rounds of chemo. And as she presses into Jesus’ strength and kindness and refining presence and promises, she shares it all online and through books and via podcasts too. There is no end to the rich offering being poured out of her during this time. 

You do not need to be battling cancerous cells yourself to be in a season of pain, desperate for the healing balm of Christ’s Word, abiding nearness, and bondage breaking power. 

I don’t usually say this here on social media, but I encourage each one of you to give  @drmichellebengtson a follow — you will find yourself blessed and encouraged I have no doubt. 

My other precious person is one of my longest most faithful friends, Kelli Stuart. 

@kellistuartauthor is not only a dear friend but a talented novelist and, I would add, a humorist. Even in the midst of great weightiness, heaviness, and seemingly crushing pressure she finds the lightness — and that comes off as Light. She is a light. 

Only a few months after a double mastectomy, midway through chemo, caring for a special needs darling boy, and overseeing the needs of an entire Ukrainian refuge family… Kelli continues to persevere, shining hope — even when hope feels slow and elusive. 

And so, today, regardless of what your cancer looks like, and where you are in the process of God’s healing — in your marriage, in your parenting, in your home or in your body, follow their lead and put your full hope in Christ for His strength in your weakness. 

I’ll be over here doing the same. 

Blessings, dear ones,

Wendy

My grandpa read through the Bible four times before he believed it. Though he attended church during his growing up years, he hadn’t yet put his faith in Christ. Truth be told, the main reason he went to church at all was because, in his own words, “That’s where the pretty girls were.”

All was going according to plan until Grandpa asked the pastor’s daughter out on a date. She asked him, on the spot, if he had put his full faith in Jesus as his personal Lord and Savior. When Grandpa couldn’t say that he had, she told him that she wouldn’t date him, then held to her conviction as he read through the Bible, cover to cover, again and again and again. After his fourth time through, he chose Jesus as his personal Lord and Savior. While my grandpa didn’t end up marrying that pastor’s daughter, she will always hold a special place in my heart.

Today, whether you are already a believer or have not yet made that decision, I encourage you to prayerfully consider reading your Bible from beginning to end, from Genesis to Revelation. The whole Bible was given to us, so give yourself the gift of reading the whole thing!

True, true, so very true. And yet… though He loves us as He finds us… He loves us to too much to leave us that way. Stuck in our sin-state. So He saves us then sanctifies us. He makes us right then, with the help of His Holy Spirit and Holy Word, enables us to live right!

Dear friend, the sanctification process is the transformation process — and God uses His Word to do the work in us. But we must join Him there… in the reading and the responding. 

The work is His to accomplish, but we actively yield and obey. It’s one of the great mysteries, how he saves and sanctifies — and yet we get to partner with Him as we trust and obey. 

God loves you as you are… but loves you too much to leave you that way. So seek His help in His transformative, sanctifying Word.

You’ll be changed from the inside out. Readily recognize what he wants from you, and quickly respond to it. Let me tell you a secret… I have a sweet friend named Jenn who works for me as a virtual assistant. She reminds me to work ahead and helps me prep for our annual fasts and other book studies. She also creates these graphics and gets my posts scheduled ahead of time so I don’t get consumed by social media. ⁠
⁠

⁠
But the truth is that she chooses verses that she knows I need to read and believe. So this one isn’t just for you, my friend. It’s for me too! ⁠
⁠
Let’s not fear, for God is with us; let us not be dismayed, for He is our God. He will strengthen us and help us; He will uphold us with His righteous right hand.” Isaiah 41:10⁠
⁠
If you are overwhelmed and falling behind, without a Jenn to keep you moving forward right now… let’s remember that God provides the Holy help we need. And if we drop balls and don’t get everything done that we committed to doing… let’s abide in His grace, in the palm of His righteous right hand. ⁠
⁠
Perspective and peace! ⁠
⁠

God has been challenging me on this one… ⁠
⁠
Reverence. ⁠
⁠
Do I come to God in His Word with a sincere reverence for Him as Creator and King? Or do I come casually as though this is merely a safe person who loves me? Both are true, which blows my fragile mind! ⁠
⁠
He is the creator of all things, from time and space to the smallest particles of matter! But he is also the gentlest, kindest, most tenderly pursuing, and unconditionally loving friend! ⁠
⁠
How vast and multifaceted and constantly surprising is his personality! If we were to pursue knowing Him all of our days… we could never know the height nor depth or width of Him. And yet He is here, as close as a breath. ⁠
⁠
Let that thought cause us to revere Him, my friend. And may our reverence for Him drive us to revere His Word, and seek Him in it! ⁠
⁠

“She dresses herself with strength and makes her arms strong… Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs at the time to come.”
‭‭Proverbs‬ ‭31‬:‭17‬, ‭25‬ ‭ESV‬‬

Proverbs 31 has been an encouragement to my heart in this weak and weary-making season — but this morning was the first time I noticed that STRENGTH / STRONG are mentioned three times in two short verses. 

I was also the first time I noticed that strength is something to be PUT ON like clothing — the same way we are told to PUT ON the Armor of God! 

I’ve always felt that strength should come from within, but this is a wonderful reminder that when we are weak God’s strength is manifested and perfected within us — but it must be intentionally PUT ON. 

When I don’t feel strong and capable from within, God is telling me to pull strength from Him — with the same active involvement I would need to walk to my literal closet and pick the right outfit for the day ahead, and then DRESS MYSELF WITH IT! 

However, strength won’t be found among my literal clothes, I have to open up my Spiritual wardrobe — God’s Word. And open myself up to the One who is the Word made flesh! 

Jesus dressed himself in the weak flesh of humanity and came to us in our weakness so that we might dress ourselves in Him and experience His strength. 

This weekend my darling firstborn came home for a visit and he brought me this necklace as a gift. 

PERFECT! 

I will remember to actively get involved in putting on God’s strength each time I PUT ON my beautiful necklace from Caleb.

Image Restored by @rachaeljgilbert is a perfect follow-up to The 40 Day Sugar Fast! This whole-person, interactive approach to body image includes coloring sheets, journaling prompts, and therapist insights that ground you in God’s love and build you up in truth.
 
Are you tired of being at war with your body—and with your thoughts about your body? Rachael Gilbert struggled with shame when she didn’t measure up to her dream body image. Then, as a fitness instructor and licensed counselor specializing in disordered eating, she realized how many of us bury the same painful insecurities. But keeping up appearances is exhausting. We need restoration from the inside out.
 
In Image RESTored, Rachael offers professional guidance, coloring pages, Scripture, prayers, journaling prompts, and a link to online teaching videos to help you experience true freedom. 

Find it on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3laZFyh

#bookrecommendation #40daysugarfast

God has seen my suffering — He has been my very personal, always abiding El Roi. 

His eye has been on me: little ole fragile me, though I’ve felt as small as a sparrow and as mistreated and afraid as Hagar herself. He has seen every moment of my present, private struggles. 

I’ve felt the warmth of his gaze upon me and it has been a comfort. He has not once turned His face from me. It’s too wonderful for words.

He has been my Jehova Jireh too, feeding me from the palm of His hand in the tenderest of ways. Seeing every need and providing for me again and again — from the biggest miraculous provisions to the minutest of details to the elusive needs of my battered heart. 

Earlier this week He did it again. I was scrolling through Instagram when I came across this picture posted by @rachelrjoy founder and operator of @_sparrowcollective — 

Though Sparrow Collective is a ministry that I had every intention of partnering with to SERVE women in crisis — I ended up finding myself in a crisis and in desperate need of help. I did not know that God would first use this generous ministry to minister to me in my lowest season! 

Twice a year the Sparrow Collective hosts a six week program called RESTORE, specifically for women who are coming out of difficult circumstances and need God’s restorative touch upon their lives. 

Most of the women who attend have not yet heard of or accepted the restorative grace and love of God. 

They are a lovely group of women who range from refuges to the impoverished, abused, and misused. Between each broken woman sits a mature and loving woman of faith, a mentor, to love and guide them to Christ, the Restorer. 

I should be a mentor. It’s who I typically am online and in ministries such as this one. But this week, Rachel and the generous servants she works with welcomed me as one of the broken. No questions asked. And I am humbled to have been so gently embraced. 

The Lord has seen me, and the Lord has provided. 

And the art therapy that is included in each week’s session is just what I needed to unlock some of my most locked up places. I can’t wait for next week!

I’ve never before identified with the hopelessness of Jesus’s disciples on Holy Saturday like I have this year. Perhaps it’s because I’ve always known the end of the story, and lived in the light of Christ’s triumphant resurrection, so even Good Friday felt… GOOD. 

But today (this year) doesn’t feel light-bright and hopeful. Today feels something-bad and altogether hopeless. Waiting for the resurrection in seemingly dead seasons can be the hardest thing ever. 

Still I wait. Still I believe. Still I praise. Still I cling. Still I persevere. Still I…. HOPE. 

Today I’m fighting for hope and choosing to believe that, INDEED, Sunday’s coming!

Today is day 3 of my own personal 40-Day Social Media Fast. I’m not really here, but these daily posts were all scheduled ahead of time to (hopefully) encourage others to take a holy hiatus too. ⁠
⁠
The first time I logged off for 40 days I invited my online friends to do the same and many said a timid yes. At the end of our fast I received a letter from a woman named Sarah who wrote: “These past forty days, my children saw my face more. That alone made it so worth it!” She went on to say that she enjoyed them more as well. I wrote back and asked her a question that has remained with me since: “Is it possible that you’ve enjoyed them more because they were more enjoyable? ⁠
⁠
Sure you were freed up to enjoy them, but was there something about their behavior that was more enjoyable too? ⁠
⁠
I’ve found that my own kids long for my attention, and when they don’t have it (when I am distracted) they naturally do whatever they need to do to get my attention. Negative attention is still attention!⁠
⁠
Ouch. ⁠
⁠
Would you consider taking a 40-day break from your online people in an effort to enjoy your real-life people? ⁠
⁠
Find out more at 40daysocialmediafast.com⁠
⁠

Hopping on the gram for the first time in 28 days because this is a moment I need to  commemorate — a lesson learned and an inky reminder for the times I forget — because I will forget and need reminding. 

Today is Mother’s Day and the message at church this morning was incredible — thank you @mattchandler74 @tvcfm 

God can be trusted to be God, even with our kids! Praise Him! 

In the margin of my open Bible I drew a small cross and an arrow with a heart shaped loopty-loop in the middle of the shaft. 

Here’s what it means to me and why my teenage boys drove me to a tattoo parlor after church this Mother’s Day. 

Shooting my three sons off toward the cross of Christ is the high calling of my life! 

While I’d love for them all to fly straight to the bullseye, without sin or detour, that’s not what any of us have done. 

“All have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God”.

Without sin we wouldn’t have needed the cross. We’ve all missed the bullseye of perfection — which is why God sent His perfect son, His sinless sacrifice. 

Every other one of us the world over and throughout all time has grieved their mother and their father and the heart of their Heavenly Father. 

Still, we’d all choose our kids to fly straight in “the way they SHOULD go”. Though all of us, like sheep, have gone astray (to varying degrees) long before our kids did. 

But the degree doesn’t matter. Sin is sin, a detour a detour, and the way back is always the cross!

And so, this Mother’s Day, I commit, as Asher’s mom, as Brody’s mom, as Caleb’s mom, and as my future grandkids’ grandma, to love with grace and perseverance through the detours. 

They are safe within my love. God gave them freewill and I will treat them with that same miraculous, mind-blowing dignity of not shaming them or berating them or demeaning them. 

May they know the freedom, the joy, and the gracious unending invitation to journey toward the cross of Christ… even on the painful loopty-loops. 

Happy Mother’s Day!

O beautiful for spacious skies,
For amber waves of grain,
For purple mountain majesties
Above the fruited plain!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
And crown thy good with brotherhood
From sea to shining sea!

O beautiful for pilgrim feet
Whose stern impassioned stress,
A thoroughfare for freedom beat
Across the wilderness! America!

America! God mend thine every flaw,
Confirm thy soul in self-control,
Thy liberty in law!

O beautiful for heroes proved
In liberating strife,
Who more than self their country love
And mercy more than life!

America! America!
May God thy gold refine
Till all success be nobleness,
And every gain divine!

O beautiful for patriot dream
That sees beyond the years,
Thine alabaster cities gleam
Undimmed by human tears!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
And crown thy good with brotherhood
From sea to shining sea!

Oh beautiful for halcyon skies
For amber waves of grain
For purple mountain majesties
Above the enameled plain!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
Till souls wax fair as earth and air
And music-hearted sea!

O beautiful for pilgrim feet
Whose stern impassioned stress,
A thoroughfare for freedom beat
Across the wilderness!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
Till paths be wrought through wilds of thought
By pilgrims foot and knee!

Oh beautiful for glory-tale
Of liberating strife,
When once and twice for man’s avail
Men lavished precious life!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
Till selfish gain no longer strain
The banner of the free!

O beautiful for patriot dream
That sees beyond the years,
Thine alabaster cities gleam
Undimmed by human tears!

America! America!
God shed His grace on thee,
Till nobler men keep once again
Thy whiter jubilee!

America The Beautiful was written by Katherine Lee Bates; (1859-1929) and inspired by her trip to Pikes Peak in 1893. Her poem first appeared in print on July 4, 1895, in The Congregationalist, a weekly journal. Ms. Bates revised these lyrics in 1904 and then again in 1913.

I logged offline a couple of months ago and have had an extremely slow re-entry. 

It’s been good. Authentic. Healthy. Needed. And honest.

It’s easy to jump back in with two feet (and multiple hours each day) as though this online sphere is our very life; where our most sincere relations exist; even the table where we are fed our most nourishing Spiritual daily bread. But it isn’t. Or, should I say, it shouldn’t be. 

Real-life is better. Time in God’s Word, getting social with Him is always better than time spent getting social with anyone and everyone else. 

If our go-to place is here… following and being followed… WE SIMPLY CANNOT KEEP OUR EYES ON THE ONLY ONE WHO GENEROUSLY INVITED, “FOLLOW ME!”

Sweet friends, don’t forsake the One who loves you for all the others who “like” you. No one else in this world (or on the world wide web) will ever satisfy your deepest needs. 

Consider disconnecting from this online space for forty days in order to reconnect with God.

I don’t think God is using this season to prepare me for what I want — but for what He wants! Then again, I want what He wants (even if I wouldn’t choose it.)

I’m reminded of John 12:24 — “Very truly I tell you, unless a kernel of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it remains only a single seed. But if it dies, it produces many seeds.”

Sometimes the fruit in your life (and through you in the lives of others) can only come when the old thing dies and gets buried in the fertile soil of your surrendered life.

In this current season of pain that I have been in I am actively believing God for not only his comfort in my life, but that I would be obedient to comfort others with the comfort He first shows me. 

“He comforts us every time we have trouble, so when others have trouble, we can comfort them with the same comfort God gives us” (2 Corinthians 1:4).

Because it’s not about you getting into the Bible… but getting the Bible into you. Nothing transforms us like God’s living and active Word.⁠
⁠
(Who needs life change? Heart change? Real and lasting change?)⁠
⁠
Your pastor’s message on Sunday was a good start, and maybe your favorite Bible teacher had a Devo sent to your email inbox too. Good start! But if you want to hit that finish line transformed more into the image of Christ, you need to dive into His transforming Word for yourself.⁠
⁠
Not sure how? Not sure where to start?⁠
⁠
Find a Bible and open it up. You can start at the beginning, in the book of Genesis. It’s the whole story of God creating the heavens in the earth and filling it with people to know and love — and know and love Him back. Another good place to start is the book of John.⁠
⁠
Both Genesis and John start at the beginning. So begin with one of them.⁠
⁠
Read chapter one then ask yourself these three questions:⁠
⁠
- What did I learn about God?⁠
- What did I learn about myself?⁠
- How do I need to live as a result of what God revealed to me?⁠
⁠
Then ask his Holy Spirit to help you live it out.⁠
⁠
I’ll be over here doing the same.⁠
⁠
⁠

DESCRIPTION:

Dads today are often overwhelmed with both the responsibility and the complexity of raising sons in this challenging culture. At the same time self-initiation is killing our young men. Without strong mentors, boys are walking alone into a wilderness of conflicting messages about who they should be as men. It's no wonder that our sons are confused about what the world expects from them and what they should expect of themselves.

The Intentional Father is a helpful antidote. This concise book is filled with practical steps to help men raise sons of consequence--young men who know what they believe, know who they are, and will stand up against the negative cultural trends of our day. Jon Tyson lays out a clear path for fathers and sons that includes specific activities, rites of passage, and significant "marking moments" that can be customized to fit any family.

It's not enough to hope our sons will become good men. We need them to be good at being men. This book shows fathers, grandfathers, and other male mentors how to lead the way.

However today goes… go to the Gospel and go with the Gospel. ⁠
⁠
Whether your heart is hardened or soft and supple. Today is a day for the Gospel to shine in the midst of a dark and crooked generation. ⁠
⁠
So what is the Gospel? Simply this: God loves us. We struggle with sin and soul-sadness and go our own way time and again. But God came running after us in our struggles to redeem us and bring us back to a right relationship with Himself. I’m talking about Jesus now. He died for our sins and our waywardness, to make us right with God the Father. But here’s the next step: once we are right with God it makes living right easier... and being right with others too. ⁠
⁠
This is the Gospel. Live right with God and others today. ⁠

ARE YOU EASILY TRIGGERED?

Do you believe your struggle with anger stems from the wrong behavior you see displayed in your children? The knee-jerk reactions and blow-ups you’re facing are often a result of a bigger set of “triggers.” Some of these are external, like a child’s disobedience, backtalk, or selective hearing, while others are internal, like an overflowing schedule, sleep-deprivation, or perhaps your own painful experiences from childhood.

THIS BOOK IS FOR YOU!

Triggers: Exchanging Parent’s Angry Reactions for Gentle Biblical Responses examines common parenting issues that cause us to explode inappropriately at our children. 

Moving beyond simple parenting tips on how to change your child’s behavior, authors Amber Lia and Wendy Speake offer biblical insight and practical tools to equip and encourage you on the journey away from anger-filled reactions toward gentle, biblical responses.

Find it on Amazon: https://amzn.to/44xqNYA

It’s true that darkness doesn’t get the final word. Here’s why: God isn’t afraid of the dark. He’s the Light of the World, so when He is in our midst no dim corner in our soul or in our mind or in our life can crowd Him out!

Psalm 139:1-12 👇🏽

You have searched me, Lord,
and you know me.

You know when I sit and when I rise;
you perceive my thoughts from afar.

You discern my going out and my lying down; you are familiar with all my ways.

Before a word is on my tongue
you, Lord, know it completely.

You hem me in behind and before,
and you lay your hand upon me.

Such knowledge is too wonderful for me, too lofty for me to attain.

Where can I go from your Spirit?

Where can I flee from your presence?

If I go up to the heavens, you are there; if I make my bed in the depths, you are there. If I rise on the wings of the dawn, if I settle on the far side of the sea, even there your hand will guide me, your right hand will hold me fast.

If I say, “Surely the darkness will hide me and the light become night around me,” even the darkness will not be dark to you; the night will shine like the day, for darkness is as light to you. 

I am so thankful that God is not afraid of the dark seasons we find ourselves in. He is the light of the World. 

Love to you

The earth trembled and quaked, and the foundations of the mountains shook; they trembled because he was angry. Smoke rose from his nostrils; consuming fire came from his mouth, burning coals blazed out of it. 

He reached down from on high and took hold of me; he drew me out of deep waters. He rescued me from my powerful enemy, from my foes, who were too strong for me. They confronted me in the day of my disaster, but the Lord was my support. He brought me out into a spacious place; he rescued me because he delighted in me. The Lord has dealt with me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands he has rewarded me. For I have kept the ways of the Lord; I am not guilty of turning from my God. The Lord has rewarded me according to my righteousness, according to the cleanness of my hands in his sight…

OK moms and dads — here’s another one for you (us) today. 

Perhaps you have the tendency to dysregulate with your chaotic kiddos rather than inviting them up into a calm and regulated moment with you. 

The struggle is real and you’re alone in it. 

First of all, so many parents are struggling too. But more importantly, you’re not alone because Christ is there in your midst and His is the peace you lack, as well as the patience and self-control. Abide in Him and bear His fruit. 

But when the fruit is slow-growing, then do the muscular work of keeping in step with His Spirit in how you respond gently instead of reacting in anger. 

Practice behaving right! When our kids do wrong WE CAN DO RIGHT. And we must. This is imperative. 

Need help? Grab a copy of our book TRIGGERS: Exchanging Parents’ Angry Reactions for Gentle, Biblical Responses. (Link in bio)

DIFFICULT POST TO POST⁠
⁠
Sometimes (oftentimes) living right means making counter-cultural choices.⁠
⁠
In popular culture today it is considered hateful and offensive to label anything as sinful or wrong. From abortion to homosexuality, taking a biblical view of the world is to take an unpopular view of things — which means you won’t be popular. (Ouch)⁠
⁠
This post-Christian world says that everyone’s truth is true and Biblical truth is exclusive and offensive. But the Gospel calls out sin for the purpose of offering forgiveness and new life. It is not unkind but the most-kind thing we could do for a man or woman making choices that separate them from God today.⁠
⁠
But, goodness, holding firm to truth and standing for it and speaking it publicly is tremendously hard.⁠
⁠
Jesus knew. He knew we would go through these very challenges in 2023, and so He told us they were coming.⁠
⁠
“If the world hates you, keep in mind that it hated me first.” (John 15:18) as a matter of fact, "EVERYONE will hate you because of me. But not a hair of your head will perish. Stand firm, and you will win life." (Luke 21:17-19)⁠
⁠
Again, it’s hard. But what a promise.⁠
⁠
Eternity must be our focus two-fold! First, we must speak the truth in love to those who are still perishing in their sin, in this world, because their eternal lives are at stake. But also, God promises us forever joy in His eternal presence when this life, riddled with persecution and other tribulation, passes away.⁠
⁠
Allow the gospel to dictate truth in your life, friend. Then stand firm IN the truth and stand FOR the truth — for the benefit of those who may not want to hear it.⁠
⁠
It is not unkind to address sin in love… in fact, there is nothing kinder. Eternity tomorrow and abundant life today is at stake.⁠
⁠

But it is finally time to wrap it up and move on. Before I do, I had to bring out my stack of “Legacy Bibles” and leave Scripture-inspired prayers in the pages of each one.

I have a journaling Bible for each one of my three sons and use the wide margins to leave prayers, blessings, and notes!

My heart is full. 

My faith is big!

Praying the Scriptures (along with Biblical themes and promises) over my boys is one of the joys of my life!

I have had friends who have the spiritual gift of refreshing. They are some of my most favorite people to be around. ⁠
⁠
#obviously⁠
⁠
I like to imagine a multi-tiered fountain with one small basin at the top spilling over the edges and into the second tier, and then from there into the next, and into the next and the next, until all the pools are splashing over in one big chorus of sacrificial praise. ⁠
⁠
That, I believe, is a picture of a healthy Christian life. It’s as though the top tier is the Love of God the Father who loved us so much that He spilled over into the person of Jesus Christ, who poured Himself out to the very end, into the person of the Holy Spirit, who was so full of love that He spilled over the edge and into every believer’s heart, and from there we are to do the same… spilling out into the lives of those in our midst. We splash into the lives of our children, our neighbors, the people in line at the grocery store, the familiar face in the pew next to us.⁠
⁠
Because we have been loved, we love.⁠
⁠
Because we have received, we give. ⁠
⁠
Because we have been comforted, we comfort. ⁠
⁠
Because we have been fed, we feed.⁠
⁠
Because we have been refreshed, we refresh. ⁠
⁠
Are you all filled up and splashing over? ⁠
⁠

If you’re hanging on by just a thread… make sure its attached to the HEM OF HIS GARMENT! 

This new book by @drmichellebengtson is a gift for those of us who are in a drawn out season of pain and suffering. 

Amazon: https://amzn.to/45xTa9M
(Link in stories)
Everyone experiences pain at times. It can manifest physically, emotionally, relationally, or spiritually. It can follow tragic accidents, great loss, sudden betrayal, or unexpected and unwanted change. Often it is temporary. But what do you do when it isn't? When the pain just won't go away, when healing does not come, when the grief and hurt settle in?

Drawing on her own experience of chronic pain and her years as a board-certified clinical neuropsychologist, Dr. Michelle Bengtson provides a countercultural perspective on pain. Offering hope without any false promises or empty platitudes, Dr. Bengtson unwraps the complex emotional aspects of dealing with pain. She gives you permission to question God, helps you identify the lies you've believed about your pain, 
and reorients your perception based on the truth of God's Word. Each chapter ends with a recommended playlist, reflection questions, and a prayer.

Insta-faith alone isn’t enough… 

However, I’ve got to say, that the accounts I follow online are a sweet encouragement to me when I am TRULY FOLLOWING CHRIST first and foremost. 

I love all the posts over at @shejourneyswithhim 

Yes, when I’m seeking Him and finding Him consistently in His Word… I am blessed to also see Him in posts on social media. 

However, If I’m not following Him in real life — all the posts I “like” on the gram can’t bring me to a place of salvation, transformation, or sanctification. Instagram and Facebook feel more like a VACATION from  the stresses of this world when we aren’t spending time with the One who made the world. 

But when we start our day being SOCIAL with God in His Word and in prayer, time on social media can remind us what is true. But it can’t ever be a substitute for real fellowship with flesh-and-blood brothers and sisters in a brick and mortar church, or time with Him in our Bibles either. 

If you need some time away from social media in an effort to get social with the Lord again (or maybe for the first time ever) consider taking a 40 Day Social Media Fast. 

Find out more at 40daysocialmediafast.com (link in bio.

Where are my desperate people who have reached out in their desperation and found God to be enough? ⁠
⁠
This isn’t some hocus-pocus… abracadabra… magic trick that removes all the hardness and heartache from our lives. No, this is the mighty strength of a loving present God in our weakness. This is His ability to comfort us when we are painfully uncomfortable. This is His presence in our present sufferings. ⁠
⁠
Oh sweet friends, if you are desperate right now, I invite you to turn to Jesus. He is not far off. He is closer than a breath. So use your breath and cry out in desperation today. ⁠
⁠
“As for me, I will call upon God;⁠
And the LORD shall save me.⁠
Evening, and morning, and at noon,⁠
will I pray, and cry aloud:⁠
And he shall hear my voice.”⁠
(Psalm 55;16-17)⁠
⁠
⁠

A SACRIFICE OF PRAISE⁠
⁠
Today is day TWO of our 30-day PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE! And I wanted to share this verse early on in the challenge because, my experience has been, sometimes giving God my thanks feels like a sacrifice. And praising Him when things are treacherously hard feels… well… treacherously hard. And yet, I’m reminded of the poor widow who came into the house of the Lord with barely enough to meet her basic needs, yet still she offered up two small coins. What a sacrifice. What an offering. Here is what we’re told in Luke 21:1-4:⁠
⁠
As Jesus looked up, he saw the rich putting their gifts into the temple treasury. He also saw a poor widow put in two very small copper coins. “Truly I tell you," He said, “this poor widow has put in more than all the others.  All these people gave their gifts out of their wealth; but she out of her poverty put in all she had to live on.”⁠
(Luke 21:1-4, NIV)⁠
⁠
Are you in a season of Spiritual poverty? Do you barely have the soul-strength to stand let alone sing? Oh, sweet friend, my lungs are quivering too. Which is why I can invite you to join me on wobbly knees to rise and proclaim the goodness of God… even in the hardest seasons.⁠
⁠
Remember, God loves the Spiritually poor. He blesses us at our weakest and our meekest. “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.”⁠
⁠
My dear friends, if today Praise and Thanksgiving feels more like a sacrifice than an overflow… how much greater the gift! So, give it today! Give it to Him.⁠
⁠
In the comment thread below give Him your humble two-coins of praise and thanks!⁠
⁠
I’ll go first.⁠
⁠
Thank You, Lord, for accepting me as I am. I am worn out to the bone. You know that. Life has been very difficult for many months. You know that too. Still, Lord, You are worthy of my thanks and praise. And so, today, I thank you for the fact You are intimately concerned with all that concerns me. You are near and never far off. You are amazing! What a comfort and what a friend. Thank You! I praise You! Amen.⁠
⁠

Praise God in his sanctuary;⁠
praise him in his mighty heavens.⁠
Praise him for his acts of power;⁠
praise him for his surpassing greatness.⁠
Praise him with the sounding of the trumpet,⁠

Today is day FIVE of our 30-day PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE! Today I am meditating on Psalm 63:3-4.⁠
⁠
I’m a hand lifter, it’s true. At church when I sing, I lift them high. When I’m out for an early morning walk and the sky is suddenly on fire with heavenly shades of pink and orange, I lift them up and then I open up my mouth and say, “GOOD JOB GOD!”⁠
⁠
When my three sons were young, I came up with a definition for the word PRAISE that has stuck with me to this day. Praise is simply telling someone what a good job they’ve done. When my middle boy was recently accepted into his first-choice college I said, “Good job!” When the youngest brother won a challenging water polo match, I wrapped my arms around his dripping wet body and shouted above the cheers of others, “Good job!” And when my first born started a business while holding down another job and then made his first big sale, again I was quick to give him my heartfelt praise with a joyful “Good job!”⁠
⁠
HOWEVER, God is the only One whose love is better than life, so He alone gets my uplifted hands!⁠
⁠
Have you told God “Good job” recently? How about we do that now! I’ll go first:⁠
⁠
Good job God! Good job with the heavens and the earth. And good job with Your Holy Spirit’s abiding nearness. Good job putting us together in families and good job giving us the local church to support us in our sanctification process. Above all, good job sending us Jesus! His job was to save us! And He did such a good job of that! Which is why we lift our hands and give Him all our praise and thanks! Amen.⁠
⁠

THANKSGIVING DAY IS NOT LONG ENOUGH…⁠
⁠
I need more than one single day to cram all my thanks and praise into. Especially since the majority of my focus that day will be on cooking and baking and making memories with loved ones. That is why this month I am challenging myself to give God ALL MY PRAISE & THANKS for 30 days! And I’m posting Scriptures and praise prompts here so that you can do the same!⁠
⁠
Today is day 6 and I am inviting God to inspire my praise with the opening line of Psalm 30, which acknowledges that He is the one who lifts us out of the depths, out of the pit… and that is the reason we exalt Him. Goodness, isn’t that my story! My life verse says it this way:⁠
⁠
I waited patiently for the Lord;⁠
he turned to me and heard my cry.⁠
He lifted me out of the slimy pit,⁠
out of the mud and mire;⁠
he set my feet on a rock⁠
and gave me a firm place to stand.⁠
He put a new song in my mouth,⁠
a hymn of praise to our God.⁠
Many will see and fear the Lord⁠
and put their trust in him.⁠
(Psalm 40:1-3)⁠
⁠
THIS IS WHY WE SING PRAISES TO THE LORD! See who Psalm 30:4 comes to the same conclusion:⁠
⁠
I will exalt you, Lord,⁠
 for you lifted me out of the depths⁠
 and did not let my enemies gloat over me.⁠
Lord my God, I called to you for help,⁠
 and you healed me.⁠
You, Lord, brought me up from the realm of the dead;⁠
 you spared me from going down to the pit.⁠
Sing the praises of the Lord, you his faithful people;⁠
 praise his holy name.⁠
(Psalm 30:1-4, NIV)⁠
⁠
Take a moment to write a lyric of praise in the comment thread below! This is our NEW SONG! Our HYMN OF PRAISE!⁠
⁠
Lord, You are my song. Thank you for filling my mouth with words of praise! You redeemed me and exchanged my own lament with lyrics of thanksgiving! May all who hear me sing rejoice in YOU! Amen.⁠
⁠

I’ve been sitting with this quote for a few days now. I’m also reading the book Red Sea Rules by Robert Morgan and have been struck by the reminder that God gave His people specific step-by-step instructions that led them to camp in that treacherous place, right by the sea with mountains on either side and the Egyptians in hot pursuit. God knew he had led them to a frightening location, but it was there He showed them His powerful saving. 

He did protect them in the end. But he did not protect them from the threat of defeat or the overwhelm of dread. 

God has been so good to me in this pitifully painfully and yet precious season I’ve been in. He is truly near and dear, communicating with His comforting companionship, His Spirit guidance, and through His Word. I’m clinging more tenaciously to Him than I I typically do. And the refining work isn’t over yet. 

God is hands on in our trials friends… always working to make us more like the Son He loves! 

Amen? 

Do you know this to be true?

I mentioned earlier this month that I have been meditating on Psalm 34 in its entirety in recent days. Honestly, I want to hide the whole thing in my heart so that it bubbles up from deep within me. Sometimes, I’ve found, it comes up out of me a verse or two at a time, other times it’s a large portion — but, most often, it is this very first sentence. Especially in the very first moments of wakefulness each morning I hear these words rise up to my mind from somewhere deep within me:⁠
⁠
I will bless the Lord at all times;⁠
his praise shall continually be on my lips.⁠
(Psalm 34:1, NIV)⁠
⁠
Before wiping from the recesses of my heart like the remainder of the sleep from my eyes or thinking about anything else, these words come to mind, a continual reminder to live a life of continual praise and worship!⁠
⁠
Of course, throughout the stressors of my day, I have to remember again and again to CONTINUE actively… and then I get back to obeying by praising. This doesn’t mean I sweep the pain under the proverbial rug… but I deal with real life as I faithfully praise the One who is faithful! He always has been faithful, He is faithful in my present struggles, and He will CONTINUE to be faithful… that is why I confidently choose to continue to praise Him!⁠
⁠
How about you? Do you need the reminder to praise Him today? Or multiple times each day?⁠
⁠
Today is day SEVEN of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE! Psalm 35:28 and Psalm 71:8 both invite us into this continual praise:⁠
⁠
My tongue will proclaim your righteousness,⁠
your praises all day long.⁠
(Psalm 35:28, NIV)⁠
⁠
My mouth is filled with your praise,⁠
declaring your splendor all day long.⁠
(Psalm 71:8, NIV)⁠
⁠
Let’s proclaim His righteousness together, right here and now, then continue to praise Him separately “all day long”! I’ll go first in the comments...⁠
⁠
⁠

Today is day EIGHT of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE! The Scripture I shared in the graphic is intended to lead us into our time of giving God our thanks and praise today. While Psalm 95:2-3 is a perfectly praise-inducing passage, the truth is that anytime I think of Psalm 95 I typically think of verses 3-7, because that was the portion that my youngest son memorized back when he was in second grade — and when he memorized it, so did his mama!⁠
⁠
Today when I think of those verses I don’t just recollect them… I hear them! But I don’t hear my voice in my mind, I hear my precious boy’s voice, back when he was a lispy little seven-year-old.⁠
⁠
(Oh, what a darling memory!)⁠
⁠
Here’s the passage we memorized together:⁠
⁠
“For the Lord is the great God,⁠
the great King above all gods.⁠
In his hand are the depths of the earth,⁠
and the mountain peaks belong to him.⁠
The sea is his, for he made it,⁠
and his hands formed the dry land.⁠
Come, let us bow down in worship,⁠
let us kneel before the Lord our Maker;⁠
for he is our God⁠
and we are the people of his pasture,⁠
the flock under his care.”⁠
⁠
I have watched the video of him reciting Psalm 95 so many times that I can’t read it or think about it without hearing his darling voice.⁠
⁠
I’m reminded of why it is that we must memorize God’s Word and tuck it into our hearts… it’s so He can speak to us from deep within us. He doesn’t wait for us to decide to open up our Bibles again, He uses the Bible passages we’ve hidden inside of us and speaks to us from there!⁠
⁠
Isn’t this another reason we should praise Him?⁠
⁠
Let’s do that now!⁠
⁠
Lord, we praise You for your Word. Thank you for giving it to us. Thank You for speaking to us through it! And, when we hide it deep within our hearts, You speak to us from deep within. It’s a miracle, and it’s marvelous! Thank You, Lord, for the joy of knowing Your voice. Amen.⁠
⁠

PRAISE THE LORD!
 
The clearest definition of the Hebrew word Hallelujah is simply this: PRAISE THE LORD!
 
It’s day TWELVE of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE and today I want to remind us to live our lives as a walking-talking Hallelujah Chorus! Whether you are experiencing heaven on earth or struggling through life’s lowest valleys; whether you are gazing up at the moon and stars with a heart eager to praise Him or drenched beneath gray rain clouds, soaking wet but still singing, whether you are in your prime, strong and healthy, or gray-haired and feeble bodied…
 
Sing a hallelujah!
 
Take a moment to enjoy the Psalm-song of praise below then add your own hallelujah chorus in the comment thread below! 
 
Praise God from heaven,
 praise him from the mountaintops;
Praise him, all you his angels,
 praise him, all you his warriors,
Praise him, sun and moon,
 praise him, you morning stars;
Praise him, high heaven,
 praise him, heavenly rain clouds;
Praise, oh let them praise the name of God—
 he spoke the word, and there they were!
 
He set them in place
  from all time to eternity;
He gave his orders,
 and that’s it!
 
Praise God from earth,
 you sea dragons, you fathomless ocean deeps;
Fire and hail, snow and ice,
 hurricanes obeying his orders;
Mountains and all hills,
 apple orchards and cedar forests;
Wild beasts and herds of cattle,
 snakes, and birds in flight;
Earth’s kings and all races,
 leaders and important people,
Robust men and women in their prime,
 and yes, graybeards and little children.
 
Let them praise the name of God—
 it’s the only Name worth praising.
His radiance exceeds anything in earth and sky;
 he’s built a monument—his very own people!
Praise from all who love God!
 Israel’s children, intimate friends of God.
Hallelujah!
(Psalm 148, MSG)
 
Amen? I’m turning one of the lines from above into my praise-prayer today…
 
Lord God, Yours is the only name worth praising!
 
Your turn…

⁠

PRAISE be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us in the heavenly realms with every spiritual blessing in Christ. (Ephesians 1:3, NIV)⁠
⁠

For, through Christ, he has blessed us abundantly more than Abraham, Isaac and Jacob had ever imagined! ⁠
⁠
Let us take time in this season of Thanksgiving to remember to thank our Heavenly Father for sending us His Son, that we might be adopted into His intimate family through His Son, our Savior and brother, Jesus Christ! ⁠
⁠
PRAISE HIM AND THANK HIM! I’ll go first: ⁠

SO THAT… It is one of my favorite little phrases in all of Scripture. God is so kind to tell us why He does BIG THINGS. Whenever I see those two little words I stop and take note. ⁠
⁠
Today is day FIFTEEN of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE  and I am meditating on the SO THAT found in 1 Peter 2:9. ⁠
⁠
But you are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, God’s special possession, that you may declare the praises of him who called you out of darkness into his wonderful light. (1 Peter 2:9, NIV)⁠
We were transferred out of the dark and into the light, out of the dominion of darkness and into the Kingdom of the Son He Loves… SO THAT we might testify to the Light of the World! ⁠
I love how the Lord inspired the ESV translation of this verse: ⁠
But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for his own possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.⁠
God chose us and called us His own... SO THAT we might proclaim the excellencies of Him who chose us and called us His own! So simple and wonderful! He first called us to faith and then commissioned us with the job of calling others to faith! He saved us SO THAT we might testify to the Savior. He called us out of darkness and into the Light that we might shine as the light of the world and testify to The Light of The World, proclaiming His excellencies!⁠
What do you say we do that now? I’ll go first: ⁠
Oh Savior, how marvelous You are! You chased me down in the dominions of darkness and used Your key to set me free! Now I live in your Kingdom of Light and I can’t stop praising You, proclaiming Your excellent qualities! My dear friends, let’s be honest for a moment and consider the words we think, the ones we read, the ones we stream… but especially the ones we speak. It has become so normal to curse and make crude jokes. And this isn’t just about dropping F-bomb. Mocking and putting others down with careless comments to them or about them can be the most harmful. ⁠
⁠
We are told so clearly in Proverbs 18:21 that “Death and life are in the power of the tongue.” The tongue can be used as a weapon of warfare or a healing balm that binds up and builds up.⁠
⁠
As we continue to prepare our hearts for Thanksgiving Day by intentionally praising Him and thanking Him every day this month, consider what words you are saying in the moments that surround your grateful exclamations of praise. Here are a couple of convicting verses that have the power to invite us up and build us up as people of the Word. Let’s be obedient to God’s refining and sanctifying instructions:⁠
⁠
Let there be no filthiness nor foolish talk nor crude joking, which are out of place, but instead, let there be THANKSGIVING. (Ephesians 5:4 ESV)⁠
⁠
Out of the same mouth come PRAISE and cursing. My brothers and sisters, this should not be. (James 3:10, NIV)⁠
⁠
Today is day SIXTEEN of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE. Let’s obey God’s Word⁠
together in the comment thread below and then out into our days. Let’s use our⁠
mouths (and our typing fingers) to PRAISE Him and THANK Him… and let’s be⁠
careful to take our cursing, crude joking, and coarse jests captive and make⁠
them bow down in submission to Christ. He came to wash us clean from all⁠
unrighteousness… so let’s honor Him by living right and talking right.⁠
⁠

Today is day 17 of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE and I feel the need to confess yet again that I⁠
am leading this series from a place of prolonged pain. Down in the dumps and⁠
downcast has been my natural bent as I’ve been bent over and broken. But the⁠
posture of praise is a gift to us when we are on our knees in weariness and weakness⁠
or joyful surrender and submission.⁠
⁠
Though I am naturally experiencing a season of hardship, I am supernaturally called to lift my eyes to God as I eagerly anticipate God’s redeeming work in our lives!⁠
⁠
I’m reminded of Psalm 27:13 in the King James translation which captures my personal experience beautifully, albeit brokenly:⁠
⁠
I would have lost heart unless I had believed That I would see the goodness of the LORD In the land of the living.⁠
⁠
Dear friends, God has faithfully turned my emotions and circumstances around before… so I’m expectant He will do it again! That’s why praising Him, even in the waiting, is possible.⁠
⁠
I’m not just waiting for Him to make me FEEL LIKE PRIASING, I’m actively praising Him, actively putting my hope in Him as I wait. “He’s the one who puts a smile on my face. He’s my God.” It’s what He does and who He is!⁠
⁠
This month we are praising God and thanking Him each day, whether we feel like it or not. I love how both of the verses below highlight PRAISE in seasons of pain:⁠
⁠
Why, my soul, are you downcast?⁠
Why so disturbed within me?⁠
Put your hope in God,⁠
for I will yet PRAISE him,⁠
my Savior and my God.⁠
(Psalm 42:11, NIV)⁠
⁠
Heal me, Lord, and I will be healed;⁠
save me and I will be saved,⁠
for you are the one I PRAISE.⁠
(Jeremiah 17:14, NIV)⁠
⁠
Let’s praise Him together today. I’ll go first:⁠
⁠
Lord, when my soul is light as air and supernaturally experiences the joy of Your Salvation… praising You is a pleasure! But even now, oh my God, the invitation remains to lift my eyes and eagerly anticipate Your goodness. Regardless of how I feel or what I am going through. You are good and You are near. So, I thank You and I praise You, my Savior and my God. Amen.⁠

Today is day 18 of our 30-DAY PRAISE & THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE and I want to encourage your heart and mine to press
pause on our petitions and just praise God for His ability to know and accomplish all that concerns us today.
 
Because of His omniscience and omnipotence, we can confidently cease and simply surrender and worship Him. We can rest, knowing all of the big scary things are in His capable hands. Nothing is a surprise to Him and nothing is too hard. Such knowledge is too wonderful for us to fathom.
 
This all-knowing, ever-present, all-powerful, and always-loving God invites us to cease from striving and even cease from asking for a day (or 30 days) and simply PRAISE HIM & THANK HIM for His ability to handle everything and anything that comes our way.

If I say, “Surely the darkness shall cover me,

& THANKSGIVING CHALLENGE and I’ve said it more than once… it’s been a doozy of a year over here. Needless to say, I understand. “Don’t fret or worry. Instead of worrying, pray. Let petitions and praises shape your worries into prayers, letting God know your concerns. I mentioned at the beginning of the month that sometimes giving God our praise and our thanks are miserably hard because life is miserably hard. How do we thank Him for what we have when what we have doesn’t seem good at all?⁠
⁠
That’s when I’m reminded of God’s invitation to bring Him our praise as a “sacrifice.” When there’s an abundance of good, it’s not difficult to spread the love and clap our hands and give Him our thanks. But when life feels heartbreakingly difficult, each thank you is a sacrifice. We’re giving away what we simply don’t have enough of.  Here’s what we’re told in Hebrews 13:15 — ⁠
⁠
“Through [Jesus Christ] then let us continually offer up a sacrifice of praise to God, that is the fruit of lips that acknowledge his name.” ⁠
⁠
Life, dear friends, can feel like we’re walking on a treacherous trapdoor, just waiting for the floor to drop out from beneath us. We’re scared. We doubt God’s goodness. Or worse, we doubt His God-ness… We can doubt that He even exists.⁠
⁠

Yesterday morning I invited you to consider with me the shepherds’ response to the angels’ great news of the Messiah’s birth. They went immediately to find the newborn King for themselves and then couldn’t help but share their great joy with others! ⁠
⁠
But today let’s consider part of the heavenly host’s birth announcement: “Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, goodwill toward men” (Luke 2:14)⁠
⁠
This is true whether we feel it or not. Even when we are at our lowest… God is enthroned in the highest!⁠
⁠
(Continued in the comments below)⁠

This is by far my favorite line of any Christmas hymn ever penned, ever sung. For it is, after all, The Good News of the Gospel. 

Each and every one of us the world over, and throughout all time, has struggled with sin. Know it or not, believe it or not, we’ve pined from that place of pain and the weight of our deserved punishment… 

But God, loving us so tremendously, didn’t want us to pay that penalty.  The cost was too high for us, and the thought of our separation from Him grieved our Creator’s heart! We were created for a love relationship with Him, after all! So, He put a rescue plan in place — and He took our place. Yes, He sent His Son, an extension of His own pursuant love, to chase us down in our waywardness. Christ paid the penalty for erroneous ways. 

And now, through faith in Jesus (His life, death, and resurrection), we’ve been brought back into a right and restored relationship with God the Father! 

Our souls can breathe a sigh of relief! 

Dear friend, our soul’s worth will always remain insecure apart from Christ because our worth is not measured by who we are but by WHOSE we are. He called us worthy of redemption. Unworthy as we were, He called us worthy. 

Mind-bending! Soul-securing!

May you experience the mystery of knowing, though miserable and undeserving, that you were and are tremendously valuable! Feel it in your soul! The One who created You for Himself devised a plan to clean you up and bring you back to Himself. 

What a price He had to pay. What a cost. Yes, it was costly. You are worth our Savior’s very life. 

“Thank You, God, for the gift of Jesus! Through whom You restored me to Yourself… and in so doing, allowed my soul to experience its worth! YOU are worthy of all my praise this Christmas season and always! Amen.

O Holy Night
The stars are brightly shining
It is the night of our dear Savior's birth
Long lay the world in sin and e'er pining
'Til He appeared and the soul felt its worth
A thrill of hope the weary world rejoices
For yonder breaks a new and glorious morn.

Fall on your knees O hear the angels voices.
O night divine O night when Christ was born
O night divine, O night, O night divine.

#christmashymns

TWENTY-ONE MORE DAYS — I know there’s much to do to get all the gifts wrapped up and cards and menus buttoned up… and I’m not telling you not to! But as you do… don’t forget to ADORE HIM.⁠
⁠
⁠
You don’t have to leave what you are doing to “come” — it’s a miracle, how very present He is. Emmanuel, God with us. ⁠
⁠
⁠
Perhaps coming to adore Him is less about leaving and going and moving about, and instead, it is a humble awareness we are coming to — coming to wake up. ⁠
⁠
⁠
Yes, the lyrics invite us to literally “come… to Bethlehem”, but might we travel there reverently in our thoughts and meditate on the miracle of it day-by-day in these days leading up to Christmas,  as the carols play?⁠
⁠
⁠
Oh Come, just think of it.⁠
Oh Come, take a moment right where you are to experience the awe of it, of Him…⁠
Christ the Lord!⁠
⁠
⁠
O come let us adore Him together! ⁠
⁠
⁠
O come all ye faithful⁠
Joyful and triumphant⁠
O come ye, O come ye to Bethlehem⁠
Come and behold Him⁠
Born the King of Angels⁠
O come let us adore Him…⁠
Christ, the Lord.⁠
⁠
⁠
Sing choirs of angels⁠
Sing in exultation⁠
Sing all ye citizens of heav'n above⁠
Glory to God⁠
Glory in the highest⁠
O come let us adore Him…⁠
Christ, the Lord.⁠
⁠
⁠
Yes Lord, we greet Thee⁠
Born this happy morning⁠
Jesus to Thee be all glory giving⁠
Word of the Father⁠
Now in flesh appearing⁠
O come let us adore Him⁠
Christ, the Lord⁠
⁠
⁠

PEACE. It’s our (long promised and highly anticipated) Christmas gift sent to us from “heaven’s all gracious King”. ⁠
⁠
⁠
This gift of PEACE was promised long before the King of Heaven sent His princely Son to fulfill Isaiah 9:6 — but fulfill it He did! ⁠
⁠
⁠
𝐅𝐨𝐫 𝐚 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞 𝐛𝐨𝐫𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐮𝐬, 𝐚 𝐬𝐨𝐧 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞 𝐠𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐮𝐬; 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐠𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐨𝐧 𝐇𝐢𝐬 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐥𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬; 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐇𝐢𝐬 𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐞𝐝 𝐖𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐮𝐥 𝐂𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐫, 𝐌𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭𝐲 𝐆𝐨𝐝, 𝐄𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐅𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫, 𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐏𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐞.⁠
⁠
⁠
I hope you’ll take a moment to read the words to the classic Christmas hymn, It Came Upon a Midnight Clear.  Written by Edmund Sears in 1849, this beloved Carol brings the celestial story to lyrical life!⁠
⁠
⁠
It came upon the midnight clear,⁠
That glorious song of old,⁠
From angels bending near the earth,⁠
To touch their harps of gold:⁠
"Peace on the earth, goodwill to men⁠
From heavens all gracious King!"⁠
The world in solemn stillness lay⁠
To hear the angels sing.⁠
⁠
⁠
Still through the cloven skies they come,⁠
With peaceful wings unfurled;⁠
And still their heavenly music floats⁠
O'er all the weary world:⁠
Above its sad and lowly plains⁠
They bend on hovering wing,⁠
And ever o'er its Babel sounds⁠
The blessed angels sing.⁠
⁠
⁠
O ye beneath life's crushing load,⁠
Whose forms are bending low,⁠
Who toil along the climbing way⁠
With painful steps and slow;⁠
Look now, for glad and golden hours⁠
Come swiftly on the wing;⁠
Oh rest beside the weary road⁠
And hear the angels sing.⁠
⁠
⁠
For lo! the days are hastening on,⁠
By prophets seen of old,⁠
When with the ever-circling years⁠
Shall come the time foretold,⁠
When the new heaven and earth shall own⁠
The Prince of Peace, their King,⁠
And the whole world send back the song⁠
Which now the angels sing.⁠
⁠
⁠

PERHAPS, THIS YEAR, WE WILL SING THESE LYRICS WITH A BIT MORE FERVOR:⁠
⁠

And ransom captive Israel⁠
That mourns in lonely exile here⁠
Until the Son of God appear⁠
Rejoice! Rejoice! Emmanuel⁠
Shall come to thee, O Israel.⁠

I have many thoughts about Israel and Palestine and those who have suffered in their shared yet separated region, but I would rather lift my prayers to heaven along with these lyrics, remembering that God sent His Son to ransom not only Jews, but all who call upon Jesus as Savior and Lord! ⁠

In the past two months, it has been my ongoing prayer that many men and women, boys and girls, in both Israel and Palestine, will encounter Jesus for themselves, accept him as their personal ransoming Savior, and rejoice. ⁠
May they all come to experience the NEARNESS of EMMANUEL! ⁠
And may you know His nearness too, and rejoice. ⁠
Blessings. ⁠

THE STORY OF AMAZING LOVE — ⁠
⁠
⁠
Need a feel-good story this Christmas? Nothing is better than The Good News!⁠
⁠
⁠
Here it is:⁠
⁠
⁠
God, the maker of heaven and earth, created YOU for a love-relationship with Himself. How wonderful is that? Love was His motive and His action. But He didn’t stop by initiating the Love story… even when Adam and Eve chose to go their own way and disobey, making a right relationship with a holy God impossible, God made it possible! ⁠
⁠
⁠
This is The Good News we call the Gospel. God’s amazing love story didn’t end when sin entered the world… in fact, that was just the beginning of His loving-pursuit to bring humanity into a right relationship with Himself yet again. ⁠
⁠
⁠
How did He do that? Well, it wasn’t through convincing us to try harder and do better and regain our right standing with Him. No matter how hard we try we will never be able to hit the mark of perfect love. Nope. Never. ⁠
⁠
⁠
So the Father sent His only Son to live the righteous life we could never live. He lived the life we should have lived and then died the death we should have died…. He took the fall for The Fall. He took the fall for ME! ⁠
⁠
⁠
 This is The Good News and The Amazing Story we sing about in the classic Christmas Hymn, Noel⁠
⁠
⁠
Love incarnate, love divine⁠
Star and angels gave the sign⁠
Bow to babe on bended knee⁠
The Savior of humanity⁠
Unto us a Child is born⁠
He shall reign forevermore⁠
⁠
⁠
NOEL, NOEL⁠
Come and see what God has done⁠
Noel, Noel⁠
The story of amazing love!⁠
⁠
⁠
The light of the world, given for us⁠
Noel, Noel⁠
Son of God and Son of man⁠
There before the world began⁠
Born to suffer, born to save⁠
Born to raise us from the grave⁠
⁠
⁠
Christ the everlasting Lord⁠
He shall reign forevermore⁠
Noel, Noel⁠
Come and see what God has done⁠
The story of amazing love!⁠
⁠

GOD ISN’T AFRAID OF THE DARK⁠
⁠
When my own dark seasons, thoughts, and feelings threaten to overwhelm my heart and mind, instead of shutting down and shutting up… I open up and look up to the One who isn’t afraid of the dark. ⁠
⁠
Psalm 139:12 reminds me: “...even the darkness is not dark to you; the night is bright as the day, for darkness is as light with you.”⁠
⁠
Lord, as we sing the lyrics to this classic Christmas hymn this year, may we be reminded that your everlasting light is still illuminating all the dark places we invite you into today. ⁠
⁠
Amen. ⁠
⁠
O little town of Bethlehem⁠
How still we see thee lie!⁠
Above thy deep and dreamless sleep⁠
The silent stars go by⁠
Yet in the dark street shineth⁠
The everlasting Light⁠
The hopes and fears of all the years⁠
Are met in thee tonight.⁠
⁠
⁠
For Christ is born of Mary⁠
And gathered all above⁠
While mortals sleep, the angels keep⁠
Their watch of wondering love⁠
O morning stars, together⁠
Proclaim the holy birth⁠
And praises sing to God, the King⁠
And peace to men on earth⁠
⁠
⁠
How silently, how silently⁠
The wondrous Gift is given!⁠
So God imparts to human hearts⁠
The blessings of His heaven⁠
No ear may hear His coming⁠
But in this world of sin⁠
Where meek souls will receive Him still⁠
The dear Christ enters in⁠

This morning I wrote the most special blessing in my three sons’ “Legacy Bibles”.

For the past couple of years, I have been writing prayers and blessings and notes of love in the margins of three Bibles as future gifts to my three teenage sons. Today I turned to the blessing of all blessings, Aaron’s blessing over the children of Israel, found in Numbers chapter 6.

From the time my firstborn was a newborn I tucked him into bed singing “The Lord bless you and keep you; the Lord, may his face shine upon you… and give you peace forever.”

As he grew up, I would sometimes change the final words, singing, “…and give you peas and carrots”, just to make him giggle. 

In two days that firstborn babe of mine turns 20, and I am still speaking this blessing over his life. 

If you are interested in starting the blessed practice of writing out blessings for your children and grandchildren in the margins of Legacy Bibles you can head on over to wendyspeake.com/legacy-bibles to see what it is I have chosen to do and links to the Bibles I use. 
 
I cannot over emphasize what a blessing it is to me to speak blessing over my children. Perhaps 2024 is the year you become intentional about speaking blessings and turning scriptures into prayers for your kids and grandkids too. Find out more and download a free guide at:

Wendyspeake.com/legacy-bibles
